text: Hey everyone, wondering if anybody has experience with a nonprofit audience? Specifically nonprofit marketers. Obviously the obstacles nonprofit marketers face are hugely different to regular marketers and I’d love to hear if anybody has any tips or advice for that audience?

elements.text: Hey everyone, wondering if anybody has experience with a nonprofit audience? Specifically nonprofit marketers. Obviously the obstacles nonprofit marketers face are hugely different to regular marketers and I’d love to hear if anybody has any tips or advice for that audience?

text: Hi everyone! Curious about how many white papers/guides/ebooks (basically, gated content) pieces you produce on a monthly or quarterly basis. Right now my team is producing about 2 per month (we have 4 personas that we market to) in order to support our lead generation programs. This pace feels like a bit much to me and I’d like to slow it down for the sake of my team’s resources. How do you manage producing gated content for multiple personas? Thanks! :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hi everyone! Curious about how many white papers/guides/ebooks (basically, gated content) pieces you produce on a monthly or quarterly basis. Right now my team is producing about 2 per month (we have 4 personas that we market to) in order to support our lead generation programs. This pace feels like a bit much to me and I’d like to slow it down for the sake of my team’s resources. How do you manage producing gated content for multiple personas? Thanks!

text: We aim for 2-4 per month—it’s a big increase from what we did previously but gated content has become a big part of our paid social strategy and our nurture campaigns. My team produces at least two written resources and then our demand gen team will often develop something like a webinar or on-demand webinar landing page.

elements.text: We aim for 2-4 per month—it’s a big increase from what we did previously but gated content has become a big part of our paid social strategy and our nurture campaigns. My team produces at least two written resources and then our demand gen team will often develop something like a webinar or on-demand webinar landing page.

text: 1 gated per year. Not by design, we just don't do it / see much of a requirement for it in our content strategy. If the content is converting, why block people from accessing it?

elements.text: 1 gated per year. Not by design, we just don't do it / see much of a requirement for it in our content strategy. If the content is converting, why block people from accessing it?

text: Thanks, <@URB31QKM4> and <@UJJFDTN8G>! Two very different answers, which I guess really highlights that this is a case by case/goal by goal strategy decision. Right now gated content is a huge part of our paid social strategy and nurture campaigns, which is why we’re producing so much. But, in general, I agree in opening up as much content as possible given our goals.

text: Definitely. There’s also a huge range of what we gate—ie we produce an annual state of the industry report which is part of a large, concerted campaign and gets a larger slice of the budget; we also produce smaller pieces like checklists/worksheets/templates for specific industries or more niche topics in our space.

There’s also a huge range of what we gate—ie we produce an annual state of the industry report which is part of a large, concerted campaign and gets a larger slice of the budget; we also produce smaller pieces like checklists/worksheets/templates for specific industries or more niche topics in our space.

text:
I think the answer here depends on your audience size (or persona size) and distribution channels. There is definitely a fatigue an audience can have with gated. So, ideally, they see gated sparingly and when they do they _know_ it’s high quality and useful to them. At least, high quality enough to give you their email!

But, this could be overthinking it. You have KPIs. Does the gated hit the KPIs? If not, it’s not the right strategy as it exists today. Rather than positioning this as “less gated” - position as “more [something else]” where you have to take resources away from gated. Be medium agnostic in how you accomplish your goals.

text: Thanks, <@UJE5LQ2JC>! I totally agree with the “more [something else]” approach and am going to use that to position our team’s work better. I think we are definitely producing enough to hit our KPIs so taking the foot off the gas in the gated arena and focusing resources on more video (which is what this approach would be for us) makes a lot of sense.

text: Thats exciting! Also I’d bet it keeps your team motivated. One can only take so many quarters of the exact same output goals…

text: I think your team's size is a huge factor here, too. Our team consists of a single content writer (me), so we're limited to about 1 gated ebook every 4-6 weeks due to other content production needs (plus 1 annual "state of..." report).

text:
Hi Alice - I worked in digital/content with a religious non-profit (an association of 1,500 churches) for a decade. In that context, the hardest thing was to cut through organizational ego and highlight/elevate constituent stories.

It was also important to understand mental models constituents held in regard to the association. We conducted in-depth “Top Task” research in order to focus UX and editorial around those items.
Any particular obstacles you’re facing?

elements.text:
Hi Alice - I worked in digital/content with a religious non-profit (an association of 1,500 churches) for a decade. In that context, the hardest thing was to cut through organizational ego and highlight/elevate constituent stories.

It was also important to understand mental models constituents held in regard to the association. We conducted in-depth “Top Task” research in order to focus UX and editorial around those items.
Any particular obstacles you’re facing?

text:
Right here, Alice!

I'm the Communications and Grants Director for an agency working with kids in foster care.
Our marketing is centered mostly around fundraising plus recruiting people to be foster parents.

Our goal is to get individuals emotionally connected to the cause. For the most part, everyone wants to 'help kids', but translating that into actual dollars is a whole other game. :grinning:

Any specific reason you're asking or something you had in mind?

elements.text:

text: Thank you <@U015K0EB865> and <@UUJBMNRNF> - really useful insights! I’m shifting some of my focus at Venngage to try and serve our nonprofit users better. We provide templates for our users to customize, and want to make sure that what we’re producing aligns with what nonprofits are making, as well as any potential roadblocks they have (like bureaucracy!) so we can try and make our marketing more tailored!

text: Hey all! For those into freelance writing - how do you usually charge writing emails for marketing campaigns? Should I charge per word or per hour? Not sure what's the best way forward. I used to write emails as a salaried writer but this is my first freelance client interested in this particular service. Thanks!

elements.text: Hey all! For those into freelance writing - how do you usually charge writing emails for marketing campaigns? Should I charge per word or per hour? Not sure what's the best way forward. I used to write emails as a salaried writer but this is my first freelance client interested in this particular service. Thanks!

text: I’d say neither! Especially for projects with a lower word count but high creativity (like email marketing) I charge per project. Estimate the # of words (i.e. 150 per email x 12 emails) and charge a premium for the low word count (i.e. if you typically charge $0.50/word, make it $0.75/word). Tally up the total and quote it as a flat price.

elements.text: I’d say neither! Especially for projects with a lower word count but high creativity (like email marketing) I charge per project. Estimate the # of words (i.e. 150 per email x 12 emails) and charge a premium for the low word count (i.e. if you typically charge $0.50/word, make it $0.75/word). Tally up the total and quote it as a flat price.

text:
Oh for sure!! I can definitely give you some examples.

We create LOTS of social media posts - as in Instagram square size - and use it for all social. We create lots of flyers to give out to schools (we also have a counseling program.) We create posters for our fundraising events and also sponsor packets/investment packages for these events. I also create 3x5 info/donation cards to hand out at events or to set at the tables. I've been creating job posting graphics to use on Facebook ads.

I'm sure there are more, but hopefully that's a good start!

One weird thing we have is we cannot show a child's face in any marketing due to confidentiality (which confidentiality is totally necessary!) This is very unlike some national charities that can really use this to their advantage and show faces.

We use lots of images with pictures of kids from behind. We also use lots of stock images - :pensive: - bc we really can't grab emotion or show what we do without showing some kids' faces. So in that vein, I would say diverse stock images with kids of all ages and ethnicity.

text:
Hey freelancers, what’s the best way to charge for writing blogs? 
• hourly basis? If yes, what’s the min n max?
• Per word basis? If yes, what’s the min n max?
• per project basis? If yes, what’s the min n max? 
Let’s assume it’s 2000 words blog.
Thanks.

elements.text: Hey freelancers, what’s the best way to charge for writing blogs?
hourly basis? If yes, what’s the min n max?
Per word basis? If yes, what’s the min n max?
per project basis? If yes, what’s the min n max?

Let’s assume it’s 2000 words blog.
Thanks.

text: i think the concept of 'solution selling' is a useful frame, both for thinking about how to sell but also how to price

elements.text: i think the concept of 'solution selling' is a useful frame, both for thinking about how to sell but also how to price

text: you're selling a solution so the answer is what is the solution worth and what cut can you take from that

text: Just like Brooklin and Laura suggested, it’s better to go with a fixed project price.

elements.text: Just like Brooklin and Laura suggested, it’s better to go with a fixed project price.

text: <@U011UJX75PE> Exactly. They don’t need to know how much time you spend on it; just the value that they get out of it.

elements.text: Exactly. They don’t need to know how much time you spend on it; just the value that they get out of it.

text:
Hi <@U0153BL0BEK>!

I always charge per project as a flat fee, based (internally) on the word count and estimated hours for the project. For two reasons:

1. “450 for the post” is a lot less scary to most clients than “$90/hr.”
2. It makes it easier to follow up with suggestions for ongoing work. (“Instead of $450/post, I can create 8 monthly posts for you for $3200.” 
Tbh, the second part of the question is a little hard to answer without more context. Some writers charge $0.03/word, others charge $1+ per word. Start with a number you’re uncomfortable with; if the customer balks, negotiate.

Then, when you have more work than you can handle, raise your prices. I’ve gone from $0.15/word to $1/word in the last couple years with this approach.

elements.text: Hi

!

I always charge per project as a flat fee, based (internally) on the word count and estimated hours for the project. For two reasons:
“450 for the post” is a lot less scary to most clients than “$90/hr.”
It makes it easier to follow up with suggestions for ongoing work. (“Instead of $450/post, I can create 8 monthly posts for you for $3200.”

Tbh, the second part of the question is a little hard to answer without more context. Some writers charge $0.03/word, others charge $1+ per word. Start with a number you’re uncomfortable with; if the customer balks, negotiate.

Then, when you have more work than you can handle, raise your prices. I’ve gone from $0.15/word to $1/word in the last couple years with this approach.

text: I usually charge per word rate as I know how much times it takes for me to write a blog post or an ebook. You need to know how much money you want to earn and how much time it takes to write a piece. Use that to come up with a per word rate. And as Brooklin said, it's less scary for clients to pay per word rate or a flat fee than what they see as a huge hourly rate.

However, I’m learning to stay within the ambit. If you have tips for that, it will help me.

elements.text: Thanks

Here’s where it gets challenging to me. On the topics that I know I’m good at, I can be definite about the time, otherwise it gets difficult for me to gauge the time. Most of the times, it goes overboard. 

However, I’m learning to stay within the ambit. If you have tips for that, it will help me.

text: Just charge a higher rate so you factor in revisions and extra time you might spend on that piece. I usually assume that it'll take longer than usual to finalize a blog post or whatever I work on. And often it takes longer! If you charge, for instance, $0.25 per word, ask for $0.30. By doing so, you'll be more comfortable taking on clients in industries you're not particularly knowledgeable about.

text: Thanks everyone. And I think the concept of solution selling is applicable to many other types of content. Will certainly see how to improve my pricing strategy with this.

elements.text: Thanks everyone. And I think the concept of solution selling is applicable to many other types of content. Will certainly see how to improve my pricing strategy with this.

text:
I think it depends.

I prefer project basis. More specifically, I work on retainer, so I do set monthly rates that bundle a few things together. Sometimes I over estimate. Sometimes I underestimate. One pro is I don't feel as much pressure to squeeze perceived value out of every hour. One con is when I underestimate, I lose money. But this style of pricing suits me and my clients. Plus, I track my hours so (in theory) I'll get more accurate. I've seen per project pricing for that length post range from $100 to $1,500+.

On the other hand, I know several talented people who charge by hour ($75-$150). Especially if some of their tasks around the writing are more nebulous, this helps ensure they're profitable. However, there's only so much they can charge per hour, so it does limit their income (depending on the niche and project).

I'd consider:
• What are you most comfortable with? 
• Which pricing structure helps you meet your income goals?
• What are clients in your niche comfortable with?
• What do clients in your niche expect? 
• Which pricing option lays the foundation for a good relationship? (e.g. which one will you need to fiddle with least? too many pricing convos can wear on a relationship)
• How can you best account for research, revisions, client communications, etc?

Plus, I track my hours so (in theory) I'll get more accurate. I've seen per project pricing for that length post range from $100 to $1,500+.

On the other hand, I know several talented people who charge by hour ($75-$150). Especially if some of their tasks around the writing are more nebulous, this helps ensure they're profitable. However, there's only so much they can charge per hour, so it does limit their income (depending on the niche and project).

I'd consider:

Which pricing structure helps you meet your income goals?
What are clients in your niche comfortable with?
What do clients in your niche expect?
Which pricing option lays the foundation for a good relationship? (e.g. which one will you need to fiddle with least? too many pricing convos can wear on a relationship)
How can you best account for research, revisions, client communications, etc?

text: Hi all, does anyone have experience with content marketing or marketing in general via Reddit? Any key things you've found? Bonus points if its in the app dev/developer space.

elements.text: Hi all, does anyone have experience with content marketing or marketing in general via Reddit? Any key things you've found? Bonus points if its in the app dev/developer space.

text: Hey Karissa, we explored it as a team when I was working on an app. Never pursued it as it felt like more of a guerilla tactic and wasn’t priority. Self promotion is shot down in a lot of subreddits and because of anonymity tracking or qualifying any sort of results is tough too. Not impossible though, and I think the more niche the product/ audience the better. Most of the stuff I read was from CMI- <https://contentmarketinginstitute.com/2019/01/quora-reddit-fuel/>

attachments.title: How to Use Reddit and Quora for Content Marketing
attachments.text: Quora and Reddit communities can be gold mines for content marketers. But you better do it right. Here’s how – Content Marketing Institute
attachments.fallback: Content Marketing Institute: How to Use Reddit and Quora for Content Marketing

elements.text: Hey Karissa, we explored it as a team when I was working on an app. Never pursued it as it felt like more of a guerilla tactic and wasn’t priority. Not impossible though, and I think the more niche the product/ audience the better. Most of the stuff I read was from CMI-

text: We recently used reddit to get feedback on a few sites we published. It helps with getting that initial traffic boost but haven’t figured out how to make it work long term like SEO.

elements.text: We recently used reddit to get feedback on a few sites we published. It helps with getting that initial traffic boost but haven’t figured out how to make it work long term like SEO.

text:
I’ve tried here and there but not on any systemic basis. The key thing I’ve found is to get involved with the community first before even considering promotion. Developers especially are already good at sniffing out marketing and they’re going to be empowered to stamp it out on reddit. The whole site is very anti self promotion.

Personally, I find reddit much more useful for ideation than promotion. I stay in touch with a lot of communities and use problems they post about as inspiration for blog posts. And I’ll try to learn about what they organically like and share.

text: These are great insights in terms of all of the factors that go into pricing! In case it’s helpful, as someone who hires freelancers specifically for b2b blog content writing, my preference for a quote would always be per-piece, eg a set rate for an article of 2,000 words. To me, the questions above are what you need to answer to determine the rate, but as the “buyer” it’s helpful to know up front what I’m signing up for so I can allocate my budget.
